newsitem.title: ITALY: ATHLETICS-GOLDEN GALA OFFERS RETURN TO BASICS.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-GOLDEN GALA OFFERS RETURN TO BASICS.

text.p: Organisers of Thursday's Golden Gala grand prix are billing the meeting as a return to basics after two unsatisfactory million dollar extravaganzas at the weekend.
Donovan Bailey won his head-to-head clash against Michael Johnson in Toronto on Sunday after the American pulled up 30 metres from the line in their 150 metres showdown.
On the previous day, Noureddine Morceli also failed to finish in his two-mile race against Haile Gebrselassie in the Dutch town of Hengelo.
"Maybe I risk being seen as behind the times but I must say that I don't like certain meetings," Italian athletic federation president Gianni Gola said this week.
"Toronto was fairground athletics. We on the other hand are offering real athletics, full of interesting duels in a programme that I believe to be extremely valid."

According to local newspapers, organisers will offer $50,000 for a world record but prefer to play down the money talk as much as possible in favour of highlighting the attractions of Rome in the summer.

"If Zurich is the point of reference for its big budget, Rome wants to be the key meeting of the early part of the season," said Gola. "The athletes have shown that they like Rome, even if there is not much money on offer."
The main duel will be in the 200 metres between Ato Boldon of Trinidad and Frankie Fredericks of Namibia, who beat the 23-year-old over 100 metres in France on Monday.

World indoor champion Hicham El Guerrouj of Morocco, who failed in an attempt to break Morceli's 1,500 metres world record at Saint-Denis on Monday, will run the distance again at the Olympic Stadium.
El Guerrouj set the fastest 1,500 metres time in the world this year at the Hengelo meeting.
World steeplechase champion Moses Kiptanui of Kenya is racing the 3,000 metres in the closing event of the evening.
Cuban high jump world record holder Javier Sotomayor will be present for only his second event since a disappointing 1996 Olympics and subsequent injury problems.
The women's events offer Russia's double Olympic champion Svetlana Masterkova her first real challenge of the season in the 800 metres against Cuba's world champion Ana Quirot
"At the moment I'm aiming everything towards the 800 metres and the world championships," said Masterkova. "The next few races will help me assess my conditions and those of my rivals."
She also has other matters on her mind.
"Shoes. In Rome I'd like to buy a nice pair of shoes," the Russian said.
